facts: Incident occurred on the intervening night of 2nd and 3rd May 1992 in Village Banskheda, Madhya Pradesh.
Accused-respondent Babulal allegedly went to the house of the deceased Ram Prasad and called him out.
Babulal allegedly took Ram Prasad towards the river.
Accused Babulal allegedly assaulted Ram Prasad with a 'lathi' (stick/cudgel) causing injuries.
Injured Ram Prasad returned home and narrated the incident to his wife Dhulibai (PW4), Mohanlal (PW2), and Chhaganlal (PW3), stating that Babulal had assaulted him.
Mohanlal (PW2) lodged the First Information Report (FIR) based on the deceased's narration.
Ram Prasad was taken for medical treatment but succumbed to his injuries.
Post-mortem examination conducted by Dr. R.C. Verma (PW1) revealed head injuries, including a fracture of the parietal bone, consistent with assault by a hard and blunt object, leading to death.
A 'lathi' was allegedly recovered at the instance of the accused Babulal.
The Trial Court (Sessions Judge, Rajgarh) convicted Babulal under Section 302 IPC and sentenced him to life imprisonment.
The High Court of Madhya Pradesh, on appeal, acquitted Babulal, primarily doubting the veracity of the oral dying declaration and the credibility of witnesses PW2, PW3, and PW4.
The State of Madhya Pradesh filed an appeal against the High Court's acquittal order before the Supreme Court.
ipc_sections: Section 300 (Murder - Definition, used implicitly for conviction under 302)
Section 304 Part I/II (Culpable homicide not amounting to murder - Considered as alternative, although conviction was under 302)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court erred in acquitting the accused by discarding the reliable and consistent oral dying declaration made by the deceased.
precedents: Khushal Rao v. State of Bombay (AIR 1958 SC 22)
State of U.P. v. Ram Sagar Yadav (1985) 1 SCC 552
Laxman v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 6 SCC 710
elements: Deceased was in a fit state of mind to make the declaration.
Declaration was voluntary and not tutored.
Declaration was consistent and corroborated by other evidence (medical, witness testimony).

counter_arguments.loophole: Minor discrepancies in the testimonies of witnesses (PW2, PW3, PW4) regarding the dying declaration, which the High Court focused on.
supporting_precedents: Surajdeo Ojha v. State of Bihar (AIR 1979 SC 1505) - Discrepancies if material can affect credibility.
Mohd. Zahid v. State of T.N. (1999) 6 SCC 120) - Benefit of doubt arising from inconsistencies.

counter_arguments.loophole: Witnesses PW2, PW3, PW4 were related or known to the deceased, potentially making them 'interested' witnesses.
supporting_precedents: Ram Manorath v. State of U.P. (1981) 2 SCC 654 - Caution advised when relying solely on interested witnesses.
Paparambaka Rosamma v. State of A.P. (1999) 7 SCC 695 - Need for corroboration when dying declaration is suspect or made to interested parties.

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court's decision was perverse as it ignored compelling evidence and drew incorrect inferences, justifying interference by the Supreme Court.
precedents: Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415
State of U.P. v. Banne @ Baijnath (2009) 4 SCC 271
Ghurey Lal v. State of U.P. (2008) 10 SCC 450
elements: High Court's reasoning was illogical or contrary to established legal principles.
High Court gave undue weight to minor discrepancies.
The view taken by the High Court was not a possible view based on the evidence.

counter_arguments.loophole: The scope of appeal against acquittal is limited; the appellate court should not substitute its view merely because another view is possible.
supporting_precedents: Ramesh Babulal Doshi v. State of Gujarat (1996) 9 SCC 225
Basappa v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 154
Ajit Singh Thakur Singh v. State of Gujarat (1981) 1 SCC 495

prosecution_arguments.argument: The medical evidence (post-mortem report by PW1) fully corroborates the ocular testimony and the dying declaration regarding the nature of weapon (lathi) and injuries causing death.
precedents: Solanki Chimanbhai Ukabhai v. State of Gujarat (AIR 1983 SC 484)
State of U.P. v. Krishna Gopal (AIR 1988 SC 2154)
Malleshi v. State of Karnataka (2004) 8 SCC 95
elements: Consistency between injuries described and weapon alleged.
Cause of death matches the assault described.
Medical opinion supports the timeline and manner of assault.

counter_arguments.loophole: Medical evidence only confirms the injury type, not the identity of the assailant.
supporting_precedents: Mani Ram v. State of U.P. (1994 Supp (2) SCC 289) - Medical evidence cannot typically prove identity.
Mayur Panabhai Shah v. State of Gujarat (1982) 2 GLR 701 - Corroborative value depends on context.

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court correctly acquitted as the prosecution failed to prove its case beyond reasonable doubt; the dying declaration was unreliable and witnesses were interested.
edge_cases: Potential for tutoring the deceased before he spoke to PW2, PW3, PW4.
Lack of independent witnesses despite the incident location potentially allowing for others.
precedents: Kali Ram v. State of H.P. (1973) 2 SCC 808 - Burden of proof always on prosecution.
Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116 - Principles for circumstantial evidence (though this case involves direct evidence via dying declaration).
Kake Singh v. State of M.P. (AIR 1982 SC 1021) - Doubts regarding dying declaration benefit the accused.

defense_arguments.argument: Appellate courts should exercise caution while interfering with an order of acquittal; the High Court's view was a plausible one based on perceived inconsistencies.
edge_cases: Presumption of innocence is strengthened by acquittal.
Article 136 jurisdiction is discretionary and used sparingly against acquittals.
precedents: Mrinal Das v. State of Tripura (2011) 9 SCC 479
Balak Ram v. State of U.P. (1975) 3 SCC 219
Antar Singh v. State of M.P. (2004) 10 SCC 605

defense_arguments.argument: Recovery of the 'lathi' is doubtful and does not conclusively link the accused to the crime.
edge_cases: Lack of independent witnesses during recovery.
Possibility of the weapon being planted or commonly available.
precedents: Mohd. Aman v. State of Rajasthan (1997) 10 SCC 44 - Weakness in recovery evidence.
Dudh Nath Pandey v. State of U.P. (1981) 2 SCC 166 - Recovery must be credible and free from doubt.
Pulukuri Kottaya v. Emperor (AIR 1947 PC 67) - Strict interpretation of Section 27, Evidence Act.

judgment.outcome: Appeal Allowed. The judgment of the High Court acquitting the respondent Babulal was set aside. The judgment of the Trial Court convicting Babulal under Section 302 IPC and sentencing him to imprisonment for life was restored.
reasoning: The Supreme Court found the High Court's reasoning for acquittal to be perverse and based on flimsy grounds.

The oral dying declaration made by the deceased to his wife (PW4) and neighbours (PW2, PW3) was found credible, consistent, and reliable. These were natural witnesses who arrived immediately after the incident.
Minor discrepancies in witness statements were considered insignificant and insufficient to discard otherwise trustworthy evidence.
The relationship of the witnesses to the deceased did not automatically discredit their testimony, especially when it was natural for them to be present.
The medical evidence (PW1's testimony and post-mortem report) fully corroborated the dying declaration regarding the weapon used (lathi) and the nature of fatal injuries.
The High Court failed to appreciate the evidence in its proper perspective and gave undue importance to trivial matters.
The Court reaffirmed the principles regarding the admissibility and evidentiary value of dying declarations.
The recovery of the lathi at the instance of the accused provided further corroboration.
